Problem Statement:
A beam of electrons is scattered by a fixed scattering target as shown in the figure. The electrons are elastically scattered. Each electron has an energy $E=\frac{5}{3} m_{0} c^{2}$ and the beam has a flux of $Q$ electrons per second.

What is the velocity of the incident electrons?
Output Format Instructions: $\frac{a}{b}c$ where $a,b\in \Z, \gcd(a,b) = 1$ and $c$ is the speed of light.
Solution: As $E=m_{0} \gamma c^{2}=\frac{5}{3} m_{0} c^{2}, \gamma=\frac{5}{3}$ and $\frac{v}{c}=\sqrt{1-\frac{1}{\gamma^{2}}}=\frac{4}{5}$. Hence the electron velocity is $0.8 c$.

Problem Statement: In an amusement park there is a rotating horizontal disk. A child can sit on it at any radius (see the figure). As the disk begins to "speed up", the child may slide off if the frictional force is insufficient. The mass of the child is $50 \mathrm{~kg}$ and the coefficient of friction is $0.4$. The angular velocity is $2 \mathrm{rad} / \mathrm{s}$. What is the maximum radius $R$ where he can sit and still remain on the disk?
Output Format Instructions: FLOAT. Unit: meters (m). Give answer to two decimal points.
Solution:
Under the critical circumstance that the child just starts to slide,

$$
m R \omega^{2}=\mu m g .
$$

Hence

$$
R=\frac{\mu g}{\omega^{2}}=\frac{0.4 \times 9.8}{2^{2}}=0.98 \mathrm{~m} .
$$

As the centrifugal force is proportional to the radius, this is the maximum radius for no-sliding.

Problem Statement: An organ pipe of length $l$ open on both ends is used in a subsonic wind tunnel to measure the Mach number $v / c$ of air in the tunnel as shown in the figure. The pipe when fixed in the tunnel is observed to resonate with a fundamental period $t$. If $v / c=1 / 2$, calculate the ratio of periods $t / t_{0}$ where $t_{0}$ is the fundamental period of the pipe in still air.
Output Format Instructions: Give the answer as a reduced fraction
Solution:
As the organ pipe is open at both ends, the fundamental wavelength of sound in resonance with it is given by $\lambda / 2=l$. The corresponding period is 

Fig. 1.221.

$$
t=\frac{\lambda}{v}=\frac{2 l}{v} \text {, }
$$

where $v$ is the velocity of sound relative to the pipe.

When the air in the pipe is still, $v$ is equal to the velocity of sound in still air, $c$, and the fundamental period is

$$
t_{0}=\frac{2 l}{c} .
$$

When the air in the pipe moves with velocity $c / 2$, the pipe can be considered to move with velocity $-c / 2$ in still air. Thus $v=c-(-c / 2)=$ $3 \mathrm{c} / 2$ and the period is

$$
t=\frac{2 l}{\frac{3 c}{2}}=\frac{4 l}{3 c} .
$$

Hence we have the ratio

$$
\frac{t}{t_{0}}=\frac{2}{3} .
$$

Problem Statement:
High-energy neutrino beams at Fermi laboratory are made by first forming a monoenergetic $\pi^{+}$(or $K^{+}$) beam and then allowing the pions to decay by $\pi^{+} \rightarrow \mu^{+}+\nu$. Recall that the mass of the pion is $140 \mathrm{MeV} / \mathrm{c}^{2}$ and the mass of the muon is $106 \mathrm{MeV} / \mathrm{c}^{2}$.

In laboratory frame, the energy of the neutrino depends on the decay angle $\theta$ (see the figure). Suppose the $\pi^{+}$beam has an energy of $200 \mathrm{GeV}$.

Find the energy of a neutrino produced in the forward direction $(\theta=0)$.
Output Format Instructions: FLOAT. Unit: GeV. Round to one decimal point.
Solution:
For convenience use units such that $c=1(m, E, p$ are all in $\mathrm{MeV})$. Consider the Lorentz-invariant and conserved quantity $E^{2}-p^{2}$. In laboratory frame, before the decay

$$
E^{2}-p^{2}=E_{\pi}^{2}-p_{\pi}^{2}=m_{\pi}^{2} .
$$

In the rest frame of the pion, after the decay

$$
\begin{aligned}
E^{\prime 2}-p^{\prime 2} &=\left(E_{\mu}^{\prime}+E_{\nu}^{\prime}\right)^{2}-\left(\mathbf{p}_{\mu}^{\prime}+\mathbf{p}_{\nu}^{\prime}\right)^{2} \\
&=\left(E_{\mu}^{\prime}+E_{\nu}^{\prime}\right)^{2}=p_{\mu}^{\prime 2}+m_{\mu}^{2}+p_{\nu}^{\prime 2}+2 p_{\nu}^{\prime} \sqrt{p_{\mu}^{\prime 2}+m_{\mu}^{2}} \\
&=2 p_{\nu}^{\prime 2}+m_{\mu}^{2}+2 p_{\nu}^{\prime} \sqrt{p_{\nu}^{\prime 2}+m_{\mu}^{2}}
\end{aligned}
$$

as $\mathbf{p}_{\mu}^{\prime}=-\mathbf{p}_{\nu}^{\prime}$, and $E_{\nu}^{\prime}=p_{\nu}^{\prime}$ assuming the neutrino to have zero rest mass. Equating the above two expressions gives

$$
E_{\nu}^{\prime}=p_{\nu}^{\prime}=\frac{m_{\pi}^{2}-m_{\mu}^{2}}{2 m_{\pi}}=29.9 \mathrm{MeV} .
$$In the laboratory frame (Fig. 3.21), momentum conservation gives

$$
p_{\pi}=p_{\nu} \cos \theta+p_{\mu} \cos \alpha, \quad p_{\nu} \sin \theta=p_{\mu} \sin \alpha,
$$

or

$$
p_{\mu}^{2}=p_{\pi}^{2}+p_{\nu}^{2}-2 p_{\pi} p_{\nu} \cos \theta,
$$

and energy conservation gives

$$
E_{\pi}=E_{\nu}+E_{\mu} .
$$

As $p_{\nu}=E_{\nu}, p_{\mu}^{2}=E_{\mu}^{2}-m_{\mu}^{2}$, the last two equations give

$$
p_{\nu}=\frac{m_{\pi}^{2}-m_{\mu}^{2}}{2\left(E_{\pi}-p_{\pi} \cos \theta\right)} .
$$

As $E_{\pi} \gg m_{\pi}$, we have

$$
p_{\pi}=E_{\pi} \sqrt{1-\frac{m_{\pi}^{2}}{E_{\pi}^{2}}} \approx E_{\pi}\left[1-\frac{1}{2}\left(\frac{m_{\pi}}{E_{\pi}}\right)^{2}\right]
$$

and hence

$$
E_{\nu}=p_{\nu} \approx \frac{\left(m_{\pi}^{2}-m_{\mu}^{2}\right) E_{\pi}}{2 E_{\pi}^{2}(1-\cos \theta)+m_{\pi}^{2} \cos \theta} .
$$

For neutrinos emitted in the forward direction, $\theta=0$ and

$$
E_{\nu} \approx\left[1-\left(\frac{m_{\mu}}{m_{\pi}}\right)^{2}\right] E_{\pi}=85.4 \mathrm{GeV} \text {. }
$$

Problem Statement:
When displaced and released, the $2 \mathrm{~kg}$ mass in the figure oscillates on the frictionless horizontal surface with period $\pi / 6$ seconds.

If a small mass is placed on the $2 \mathrm{~kg}$ block and the coefficient of static friction between the small mass and the $2 \mathrm{~kg}$ block is $0.1$, what is the maximum amplitude of oscillation before the small mass slips? (Assume the period is unaffected by adding the small mass.)
Output Format Instructions: FLOAT. Unit: m. Give an answer in the form $r \times 10^m$ where $0\le r < 10$ and $m$ is some positive integer. $r$ should be rounded to 1 decimal place.
Solution:
Let $k$ be the spring constant. The equation of the motion of the mass is

$$
2 \ddot{x}+k x=0,
$$

or

$$
\ddot{x}+\omega^{2} x=0,
$$

where $x$ is the displacement of the block from its equilibrium postition, and $\omega^{2}=\frac{k}{2}$. The general solution is

$$
x=A \cos (\omega t+\phi) .
$$

The period of oscillation is

$$
T=\frac{2 \pi}{\omega}=2 \pi \sqrt{\frac{2}{k}}=\frac{\pi}{6},
$$

giving $\omega=12 \mathrm{~s}^{-1}, k=288 \mathrm{Nm}^{-1}$. If $\dot{x}=x_{0}$ at $t=0$, then $\phi=0, A=x_{0}$ and the solution is $x=x_{0} \cos (12 t)$.

The force needed is

$$
f=k x=288 \times 2 \times 10^{-2}=5.76 \mathrm{~N} .
$$

If the small mass moves together with the $2 \mathrm{~kg}$ block, it has the same acceleration as the latter, i.e. $\ddot{x}=-144 x_{0} \cos (12 t)$. Let its mass be $m$. When it starts to slip, the maximum horizontal force on it just exceeds the static friction:

$$
0.1 \times m g=144 m x_{0},
$$

giving

$$
x_{0}=\frac{0.98}{144}=6.8 \times 10^{-3} \mathrm{~m} \text {. }
$$

If $x_{0}$ exceeds this value $m$ will slip. Hence it gives the maximum amplitude for no slipping.

Problem Statement: A stepladder consists of two legs held together by a hinge at the top and a horizontal rope near the bottom, and it rests on a horizontal surface at $60^{\circ}$ as shown in the figure. If the rope is suddenly cut, what is the acceleration of the hinge at that instant? Assume the legs to be uniform, identical to each other, and neglect all friction.
Output Format Instructions: $\frac{a}{b}g$ where $a,b\in \Z, \gcd(a,b) = 1$ and $g\approx 9.81m/s^2$ is the gravitational acceleration near the Earth's surface .
Solution:
Consider the instant when the horizontal rope is suddenly cut.

By symmetry the forces which the two legs exert on each other at the hinge $A$ are horizontal and the acceleration of $A, \mathbf{a}_{A}$, is vertically downward.

Consider one leg of the stepladder. The forces acting on it are as shown in Fig. 1.176. Let $l$ be the length of the leg and $\mathbf{a}_{C}$ the acceleration of its center of mass $C$ at the instant the rope is cut. We have 

$$
\begin{gathered}
m g-N=m a_{C y}, \\
F=m a_{C x}, \\
\frac{1}{2} N l \cos 60^{\circ}-\frac{1}{2} F l \sin 60^{\circ}=I \ddot{\theta}
\end{gathered}
$$

with $I=\frac{1}{12} m l^{2}$, or

$$
N-\sqrt{3} F=\frac{1}{3} m l \ddot{\theta} .
$$

The velocity of $A$ in terms of the velocity of $C$ are given by

$$
\dot{x}_{A}=\dot{x}_{C}-\frac{1}{2} l \dot{\theta} \sin 60^{\circ}, \quad \dot{y}_{A}=\dot{y}_{C}+\frac{1}{2} l \dot{\theta} \cos 60^{\circ} .
$$

Hence $\mathbf{a}_{\boldsymbol{A}}$, which is in the $y$ direction, has components

$$
\begin{aligned}
0 &=a_{C x}-\frac{\sqrt{3}}{4} l \ddot{\theta}, \\
a_{A} &=a_{C y}+\frac{1}{4} l \ddot{\theta} .
\end{aligned}
$$

Consider now the acceleration $\mathbf{a}_{B}$ of point $B$. At the instant the rope is cut it has only a horizontal component. Thus $a_{B_{y}}=0$, i.e.

$$
a_{C y}-\frac{1}{2} l \ddot{\theta} \cos 60^{\circ}=a_{C y}-\frac{1}{4} l \ddot{\theta}=0 .
$$

The above consideration gives

$$
a_{C x}=\frac{\sqrt{3}}{4} l \ddot{\theta}, \quad a_{C y}=\frac{1}{4} l \ddot{\theta} .
$$

Using these in the equations of motion for $C$ we find

$$
\ddot{\theta}=\frac{3 g}{4 l},
$$

which gives the acceleration of the hinge as

$$
a_{A}=\frac{1}{2} l \ddot{\theta}=\frac{3}{8} g,
$$

directed vertically downward.

Problem Statement: The two flywheels in the figure are on parallel frictionless shafts but initially do not touch. The larger wheel has $f=2000 \mathrm{rev} / \mathrm{min}$ while the smaller is at rest. If the two parallel shafts are moved until contact occurs, find the angular velocity of the second wheel after equilibrium occurs (i.e. no further sliding at the point of contact), given that $R_{1}=2 R_{2}, I_{1}=16 I_{2}$.
Solution:
Suppose the impulse of the interacting force between the two wheels from contact to equilibrium is $J$. Then the torque of the impulse acting on the larger wheel is $J R_{1}$ and that on the smaller wheel is $J R_{2}$.

We have $I_{1}\left(\omega_{1}-\omega_{1}^{\prime}\right)=J R_{1}, I_{2} \omega_{2}^{\prime}=J R_{2}$, where $\omega_{1}$ and $\omega_{1}^{\prime}$ are the angular velocities of the larger wheel before contact and after equilibrium respectively, and $\omega_{2}^{\prime}$ is the angular velocity of the smaller wheel after equilibrium. As there is no sliding between the wheels when equilibrium is reached,

$$
\omega_{1}^{\prime} R_{1}=\omega_{2}^{\prime} R_{2} .
$$

The above equations give

$$
\omega_{2}^{\prime}=\frac{I_{1} R_{1} R_{2} \omega_{1}^{\prime}}{I_{1} R_{2}^{2}+I_{2} R_{1}^{2}}=1.6 \omega_{1}=3200 \mathrm{rev} / \mathrm{min} .
$$
